Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation: Investigating Engineering Students Habits of Mind: A Case Study Approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The problems facing engineers in the 21st century are highly complex, involving often competing requirements related to available technology, societal needs, environmental considerations, and others. Fostering the ability of students to solve these complex problems requires going beyond teaching technical skills to consider the way engineers think. This project is an interdisciplinary study that aims to characterize undergraduate engineering students' "habits of mind", which are modes of thinking required for engineering students to become effective problem solvers capable of transferring such skills to new contexts. An example of habit of mind is a willingness to make mistakes while trying to solve a problem, an attitude that allows engineers to successfully attack problems that were previously unsolved. Students who have these habits of mind will be prepared to address complex issues such as those described in the NAE Grand Challenges.

The project will leverage an education website called Rhea (www.projectrhea.org) along with data acquired as part of an engineering course to identify how students experience scientific habits of mind as they engage in problem solving. To this end, qualitative and quantitative research methods enhanced with machine learning techniques will be combined. This will be accomplished through an interdisciplinary partnership in which a boundary spanning research program to identify and validate novel research methods and formative and summative assessment mechanisms will be initiated. The efforts will center on enhancing qualitative and quantitative educational research and assessment methods with machine learning techniques such as automatic data clustering. The rationale for this project is that its successful completion will (a) enable the research team to develop collaborative inter-disciplinary efforts where the PI Boutin will develop expertise in educational research methods and the co-PI Magana will develop expertise in machine learning; (b) provide a context for an exploratory study to be used as a baseline to apply for future funding to establish a program in engineering education research methods and assessment; (c) address challenges in cultivating a culture of lifelong learning among professional and future engineers via scientific habits of mind in an engineering context; and (d) develop new methods to characterize and measure different aspects of professional formation processes in engineering education. The long term vision is to develop an interdisciplinary partnership in the field of machine-learning-assisted education research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
?Habits of mind? are the modes of thinking (e.g., mathematical and logical skills) required for science, mathematics, technology and engineering students to become effective problem solvers capable of transferring such skills to new contexts. This project had two main outcomes. (1) the identification of patterns of habits of mind associated with different course outcomes among undergraduate engineering students; (2) the development of data transformation and machine learning tools to analyze educational data, even small datasets (e.g., 25 students), at a detailed level by identifying groups of students with similar characteristics. 

Intellectual Merit: This interdisciplinary partnership initiated a boundary spanning research program to identify and validated novel research methods and formative and summative assessment mechanisms. The efforts enhanced qualitative and quantitative educational research and assessment methods with signal processing and machine learning techniques such as automatic data clustering. The conceptual framework of habits of mind guided this investigation.

One first outcome was a rubric to characterize students' habits of mind as demonstrated through learning material they developed and posted online. The material consisted of a self-created lecture (based on an instructor's lecture) herein called slecture, plus a process of peer review. Our findings indicate the presence of several statistically significant patterns of Habits of Mind which are related to course performance. In particular, the course grade is found to be dependent on at least two Habits of Mind ("computation and estimation" and "values and attitudes"). 

A second outcome related to the effectiveness of simulation tools for conceptual understanding among middle school students. We found the presence of several statistically significant patterns of conceptual understanding which are related to both course performance and improvement over the course. In particular, students whose pattern of conceptual understanding fell short of the other ones ("high performers") at the beginning of the semester were found to improve more than the high performers after instructional intervention in both contextual and conceptual understanding. 

 A third outcome is the development of a method to encode qualitative data in a quantitative form that can be used as the input of standard machine learning algorithms. The method builds on the use of rubric tags to model each student's data as a random process: the parameters of the random process are used in a feature vector representing each student.

Our fourth outcome is a method to find binary patterns among students. The method applies to a small number of student subjects, as well as large ones. The method uses a binary clustering method called n-TARP that involves projections onto random one-dimensional linear subspaces in order to effectively cluster small sets of high-dimensional data corresponding to the aforementioned feature vectors. 

A fifth outcome is a strong and deep partnership between two researchers with complementary expertizes, namely machine learning and education, who have come together and improved on existing methods to analyze data in engineering education research. This partnership is now moving on to the next level with a grantsmanship strategy and already secured funding.  

Broader Impact: 

The need for the math and science foundation in engineering students? education to incorporate less defined but necessary skills such as persistence and willingness to take calculated risks has been acknowledged by many. This project addressed challenges in cultivating a culture of lifelong learning among professional and future engineers via scientific habits of mind in an engineering context; and developed new methods to characterize and measure different aspects of professional formation processes in engineering education. 

The teaching methods and learning strategies that can promote engineering students? scientific habits of mind resulting from this project with this project will have a direct impact on the Electrical and Computer Engineering discipline. Similarly, research methods implemented in our studies will impact other social sciences disciplines by creating new analytical procedures or implementing not-widely applied existing ones at the intersection of computer science and education. Thus, the outcomes of this project are likely to make an impact on other engineering disciplines and social science disciplines.
